Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the father needs to prepare for it
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: They are sorting files that contain detailed medical histories that must not be disclosed.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my laptop open to the family budget spreadsheet. The numbers glared at me—our home loan repayment was due in two months, and I needed to make sure we had enough saved. My wife trusted me to keep us afloat, and I felt the weight of that responsibility pressing on my chest. But today, I was also scheduled to volunteer at the community center, sorting files for the free clinic. As I sifted through folders filled with medical histories, I reminded myself how crucial it was to respect the privacy of every person whose name I saw. The director had emphasized confidentiality, and I knew how much these families depended on our discretion. Yet, as I glanced at one file, I recognized a neighbor’s name—someone who might be able to help me find extra work. The urge to reach out, to ask for a job lead, gnawed at me. But doing so would mean breaking the trust I’d promised to uphold. My mind spun between the need to provide for my family and the duty to protect the people I was helping. I sat there, torn, unable to move forward.
